entry.title: Discover what’s new in SAP Signavio’s major Process Landscape Analysis update this November
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced ERP transformation landscape, achieving process transparency, harmonization, and efficiency is critical. Organizations migrating to SAP S/4HANA face the challenge of aligning complex business processes across multiple units while ensuring adoption of standardized templates. SAP Signavio’s Process Landscape Analysis (PLA), as part of the plug and gain approach, addresses these challenges by providing a structured, data-driven way to manage and optimize processes throughout the transformation journey. All essentials and key resources regarding plug and gain approach can be found here.

The latest update of the PLA introduces new content, an improved user experience and a completely new dashboard, making process harmonization easier and more actionable than ever. 

In this blog, you will get a high-level overview of:

  • The latest updates to Process Landscape Analysis and its new structure
  • The new Adherence to Target Processes dashboard and its key insights

 

The Process Landscape Analysis

First: what's new in the update?

The latest major PLA update delivers more and deeper content and new capabilities to track harmonization and ensure process adherence. The image below gives a clear overview of the current version and everything that will be added new. 

 

Understanding the Process Landscape Analysis 

What does this mean? To give a bit more context, let’s dive a bit more into the process landscape analysis and how it is built up. At its core, Process Landscape Analysis offers a consolidated view of the processes running in an ERP system by combining several modules of the SAP Signavio Suite. Built on three key components, it allows organizations to understand current process performance, identify process variants, and monitor adherence to target processes:

  • The Process House – Provides a top-down structure for navigating individual processes. It aggregates information at the end-to-end process level and company level, giving stakeholders a complete overview of process execution across the organization.
  • Individual Processes – Each process is analyzed for execution, variants, and transaction code usage. The Best-Run Score (BRS) evaluates process effectiveness and efficiency, helping identify high-volume processes that may need optimization.
  • Adherence to Target Processes Analysis – Compares actual execution with defined target process variants to monitor compliance, enforce standardization, and support the rollout of ERP templates.

Together, these three components create a comprehensive view of your ERP processes, laying the foundation for informed decisions and a successful transformation journey. The following video shows how it looks like. 

 

Adherence to Target Processes

A cornerstone of the update is the Adherence to Target Processes dashboard, which enables organizations to track harmonization and ensure process adherence in SAP transformation projects. The dashboard comes with the following analysis:

  • Current Process Variants Analysis – Provides a snapshot of process variants used across organizational units, highlighting inconsistencies and opportunities for standardization.
  • Comparison Against Target Processes – Measures adherence to defined templates, revealing deviations and guiding corrective actions, such as training or process refinement.
  • Assessment of Target Processes – Identifies rarely or never used variants, enabling deprecation and maintaining a lean ERP template.

For instance, if a rollout introduces a new procurement process, the dashboard shows which units follow the target process, where deviations occur, and which legacy variants may require retirement, ensuring operational efficiency and governance.

 

Challenge: Ensuring Consistent Execution Across Organizational Units

When customers define a template for their ERP system, they typically specify multiple process variants for each process. In each ERP system, customers are running many processes. This is called the ERP-Template. With Plug and Gain Process Landscape Analysis, customers can measure the actual process execution across more than 100 processes right out of the box.

Typical questions customers ask: 

To which extent does our actual process execution match with the ERP template? Where do we need to reinforce the rollout?

But it’s not enough to see this at a global level.. Typical customers have > 1,000 combinations of processes and organizational units. We need the transparency by process and organizational unit. That’s where the new adherence to target processes dashboard comes in!

 

Why Process Harmonization Matters

Process harmonization is essential for consistent, efficient, and compliant operations across an organization. It ensures that business processes are executed uniformly to reduce complexity, improve quality, and drive measurable business outcomes.
Successful harmonization strengthens both the top line (better customer experience, better financial results, faster execution) and the bottom line (cost reduction, standardization, and compliance). Yet, many organizations struggle to achieve this consistency, especially when multiple systems, tools, and organizational units are involved.

 

SAP Learning Journey available

In addition, we offer the following SAP Learning Journey, which provides a comprehensive guide to Process Landscape Analysis, including detailed explanations of each analysis, supporting video tutorials and how it could be applied in SAP Activate..

entry.title: Re: lms.sapsf.com Cert Renewal Notifications from SAP
entry.content:
Hi @jalpanthakkar34,

According to the KBA 2533915 - SAP SuccessFactors SSL Certificate Renewal Schedule and Public Certificate Repository - SAP for Me, in the FAQ section:

Q: How do I download or install the certificate?
A: You must have admin access to the server where you need to install the certificate. If you do not have access to your company's SSL server, notify your IT team and provide them the respective certificate download link from the above table. For SuccessFactors certificates in CPI landscape, you can follow KBA  2776681 - How to maintain SuccessFactors certificates in CPI landscape - Cloud Platform Integration”.

To perform the upload of the certificate, after downloading the certificate from the Attachments section of this KBA, it should be handed to your internal IT resources. The reason is because the certificate updates are applied on your third-party servers, and this is done by those servers' admins - which is generally deferred to the customers' IT.

BR

entry.title: Re: Successfactors - Salary review performancehistory
entry.content:
Hi @Maria851 

There is no direct mapping available between values in the standard performance history background element and columns of Compensation templates).

Here are your only choices to display performance rating history :

  • Create a custom link (will show when clicking on employee dots next to employee name) with the performance history background element.
  • Use the workaround (Perf History portlet to MDF through IC then to Comp column) documented in this blog.

I always challenge this requirement when I get it because Comp reviews are supposed to be based on the latest performance, not on your performance history. And it's all available on the employee profile already for comp planners.

All the best,

Xavier

entry.title: Re: I acquired an asset in 2022 and capitalized it on Oct...
entry.content:
Good day @ALI_HASSAN58 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Depreciation Areas, Unplanned Depreciation Expense, Manual Planning of Depreciation, Transfer Postings

Restricting Transaction Types to Depreciation Areas

The error message you provided highlights discrepancies between your transaction type year category and the acquisition posting year of your asset.

To summarise, in public cloud, the system enforces strict controls on unplanned depreciation posting to maintain compliance with IFRS and its clean-core accounting principles. The system interprets this as a prior-year acquisition and transaction types for unplanned depreciation must align with the 640 (for current-year acquisitions) and 650 (for prior-year acquisitions not prior YEARS) classification.

That means, the system will reject your posting if:

  • The wrong transaction type is used
  • You attempt to depreciate beyond the allowable residual value. An example would be depreciating more than book value minus scrap.
  • Both prior-year and current-year values exist and therefore it requires separate posting split by acquisition category.

Your 5% depreciation key scrap value setting was correct but not relevant to the manual transaction logic.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: From Data to Delight—How SAP CX AI Toolkit Transforms Customer Experiences
entry.content:
Introduction
As customer’s needs evolve at lightning speed, it’s more important than ever for businesses to truly tap into their data and unlock new possibilities to stay one step ahead. The SAP CX AI Toolkit is revolutionizing how organizations automate, streamline, and enhance customer interactions. By blending next-generation AI with advanced data analytics, the toolkit accelerates productivity and reveals actionable insights across sales, service, and commerce domains. Additionally, Joule—the integrated AI copilot—offers a seamless interface for accessing all the toolkit’s power.

Why SAP CX AI Toolkit?

SAP CX AI Toolkit bridges operational silos, bringing together CRM, email, and business systems to create efficient, role-specific workflows. With Generative AI features, it streamlines repetitive tasks, delivers proactive business intelligence, and empowers your teams to make smarter decisions—saving you hours and driving tangible results.

Key Benefits

  • Informed Decisions: Combine enterprise and operational data to empower intelligent, data-driven choices.
  • Automated Tasks: Eliminate manual effort by automating routine actions within your team’s existing workspace—whether in a dedicated app or through Joule.
  • Faster Customer Response: Quickly understand customer needs and respond with timely, AI-powered insights derived from comprehensive enterprise data.

Comprehensive Features & Highlights

  1. Role-Specific AI Tools
    The toolkit delivers specialized AI capabilities tailored to vital CX roles:
  • Customer communication automation
  • Summarization of records and meetings
  • Object and image recognition
  • Contextual prompts for sales, service, and marketing
    These tools enable every team to work faster and smarter.
  1. Robust Data Protection
    With best-in-class personal data protection and zero data retention policies, SAP CX AI Toolkit ensures your sensitive enterprise information remains secure and compliant.
  2. Multi-Source Data Integration
    Aggregate and analyze data from diverse systems—Sales, Service, Commerce, CDP, Microsoft 365—and unlock insights across every customer touchpoint.
  3. Configurable Tools
    From data sources to generative templates and prompts, every element is tailored to your organization’s needs, allowing a customized CX automation strategy.

Persona-Based Licensing
SAP CX AI Toolkit’s functionality is organized around three distinct licenses—usable individually or combined, based on your operational persona:

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
  • SAP Service Cloud Version 2
  • SAP Commerce Cloud

Each license unlocks targeted features:

License Type

Key Tools & Features

All Licenses

Intelligent Q&A, Smart Actions, Meetings, Scheduling

Sales Cloud V2

Opportunity Summarization, Prospecting Emails, Discovery Call Questions

Service Cloud V2

Case Overview, Customer Service Responses, Knowledge Base Article Creation

Combined Licenses

Meeting Summaries, Follow-up Emails, Account Overviews

Commerce Cloud

Product Attributes, Descriptions, Image Generation, Visual Search, Blog & Social Posts

 

User Interfaces: Accessing SAP CX AI Toolkit
The toolkit is flexibly accessible through several user interfaces:

  • Web App: Log in using SAP or Microsoft credentials to set up your tenant and access tools as per your license. The web app features an intuitive dashboard, a searchable Q&A bar, customizable AI panels, real-time notifications, and process monitoring.
  • Chrome Extension (Joule): Installable from the Chrome Web Store, Joule places AI functionality at your fingertips across business applications like Outlook Web, SAP Cloud for Customer, and SAP Commerce Cloud. Features are context-aware and can be accessed directly as a browser overlay.
  • Embedded Panel: Integrated into SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 as a right-side panel, delivering the full web app experience in-context with contact, account, case, and opportunity data.

In-depth Feature Exploration

Intelligent Q&A
Leverages Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) to provide precise, natural-language answers to work-related questions by drawing from your enterprise sources—emails, meeting transcripts, documents, service tickets, product specs, and more. Data privacy is built-in, with no personal data stored in AI models.

Generative AI Tools
Adapted for three core ecosystems, these tools automate:

  • Microsoft 365: Meeting summaries and follow-up emails
  • SAP C4C, Sales & Service Cloud V2: Account/Opportunity summaries, prospecting emails, case overviews, customer service responses, knowledge base articles, discovery call questions
  • SAP Commerce Cloud: Blog/social media post generation, product banner text, ATP inquiries, product review summaries

SAP Commerce Cloud Features

  • AI Product Tagging: Automatically generate and enrich product attributes.
  • Product Description Generation: Create and translate compelling catalog and marketing texts.
  • Product Image Generation: Enhance images, add overlays, and edit visuals.
  • Visual Search: Find catalog products using user-uploaded images—transforming discovery and search.

AI Tools Builder & Agents
Customize the toolkit with AI tools and intelligent agents tailored to your business needs, such as service classification, knowledge base article generation, shopping advice, quote automation, and catalog optimization.

Persona-Based Use Cases

Sales Cloud V2:

  • Combine emails, chats, and sales data for rich insights
  • Generate dynamic content for effective sales outreach
  • Quick, trustworthy answers and efficient interaction summaries
  • Personalized prospecting emails and targeted follow-up actions

Service Cloud V2:

  • Streamline case management and service responses
  • Auto-generate knowledge base content
  • Leverage smart scheduling and notifications for efficient service delivery

Commerce Cloud:

  • Enrich product content and images with AI
  • Automate catalog descriptions and visual searching
  • Drive engagement through AI-powered blog and social posts

Custom AI Tool API Support

The SAP CX AI Toolkit also empowers developers with Custom AI Tool API Support—a set of Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) that enable seamless integration of advanced, tailor-made Artificial Intelligence solutions within external applications. This means organizations can extend AI-driven outcomes to new business scenarios, connecting their unique workflows and data landscapes with the intelligence of SAP CX AI Toolkit agents.

Smarter Customer Engagement with AI Agents

SAP CX AI Toolkit features AI agents—Shopping Agent and Digital Service Agent—each designed to address distinct phases of the customer journey.

Shopping Agent: Your Digital Sales Associate

The Shopping Agent transforms your commerce storefront by engaging customers through natural language conversations. Acting as a knowledgeable digital associate, it understands everything from specific requests—such as “I need a lightweight rain jacket”—to broader needs like “I’m planning a beach vacation.” The agent instantly provides tailored responses, including details about product features, compatibility, and recommendations.

Configuration is flexible, you can integrate the Shopping Agent directly into your online catalog using SAP CX AI Toolkit, and the agent converses in the customer’s language. Purpose-built for both B2B and B2C scenarios (activated via API configuration), the Shopping Agent proactively interacts with customers, refining product suggestions through relevant follow-up questions and guiding them throughout their shopping experience.

Key Capabilities of the Shopping Agent include:

  • Helping customers find and compare products using conversational AI.
  • Understanding and processing complex customer queries through intuitive dialogue.
  • Integrating seamlessly with your e-commerce storefront via a robust, flexible API.

Knowledge Base Integration:
The Shopping Agent can process unstructured data in varied formats as part of its knowledge base. By uploading product manuals, catalogs, or specification documents (PDF, image, text, spreadsheet formats, etc.) to SAP Commerce Cloud, you arm the agent with deep, detailed product knowledge to answer nuanced customer queries.

Digital Service Agent: Intelligent Post-Purchase Support

The Digital Service Agent is designed to deliver top-tier, automated customer support in natural language. Leveraging specific business knowledge sources—configured by your administrator—it answers post-purchase inquiries, resolving common issues and freeing up your service team for escalated cases.

This agent can operate solo or alongside the Shopping Agent, providing unified and continuous support throughout a customer’s lifecycle. For example, after a purchase, a customer with a warranty question interacts with the Digital Service Agent, who pulls relevant information—even translating responses if needed for multilingual scenarios.

Key Capabilities of the Digital Service Agent include:

  • Operating 24/7 to provide answers using precise business knowledge sources (manuals, FAQs, service tickets).
  • Handling service-related requests such as checking order status, processing returns, or addressing product issues.
  • Assisting in both B2B and B2C environments, with API-driven flexibility.

Comparison: Shopping Agent vs. Digital Service Agent

Feature

Shopping Agent (Digital Sales Associate)

Digital Service Agent (Customer Support)

Primary Goal

Drive sales, product discovery, pre-purchase assistance

Resolve service issues, post-purchase customer support

Key Functions

Recommends products; provides features/specs/compatibility info

Answers inquiries (warranties, returns, order status); FAQs

Data Sources

Product catalog & related documents/media

Knowledge base, service tickets, admin-configured sources

Integration

Direct commerce storefront integration

Standalone or in tandem with Shopping Agent

Focus

Product- and sales-oriented

Service- and resolution-oriented

 

In essence, the Shopping Agent is your digital sales expert, while the Digital Service Agent is your first-responder customer service assistant. Integrated together, they deliver a seamless, unified customer experience across all stages of the journey.

Conclusion
SAP CX AI Toolkit is more than a set of AI tools—it’s an innovation engine for your customer experience strategy. With deep integration, robust security, and persona-driven features, businesses can transform the way data is leveraged to create exceptional customer and employee experiences. Whether accessed via the web app, Chrome extension, or embedded panels, SAP CX AI Toolkit is ready to propel enterprises into the future of AI-powered customer interactions.

entry.title: Agentic Databases for Data Scientists: SAP HANA Cloud Will Equip You with a Team
entry.content:
During my tenure as a data practitioner, I often preferred my own database to produce mission-critical calculations. The journey of such an analysis usually began with a single purpose, like informing a business process manager or a change of parameters to optimize a back-end process. Regardless of the original scope, the need to operationalize the logic often followed.

data professional in front of two monitors

Moonlighting as a DBA was nice, admittedly, because I could manage my databases with minimal process obstacles . However, the time lost searching documentation and stuck in trial-error loops of administrative commands only increased the delivery pressure, as deadlines are often unforgiving. I very quickly learned that while I was certainly capable of performing a dual role, I could not be great at both. The expectations of my job demanded data analysis excellence, while I desperately sought after administrative competency.

Last week at SAP TechEd 2025, the SAP HANA Cloud team made a few significant announcements. One very notable set of features is the introduction of the agentic database concept. Simply illustrated and grounded in my scenario, the use of AI agents could give me the best of both worlds – autonomy and scale. Applying the example, imagine the productivity benefits associated with giving every data science professional a dedicated team of agentic colleagues – administrator, data analyst, and a multi-model specialist.

SAP HANA Cloud agents

For those who prefer the native use of a database, consider the upcoming agentic features of SAP HANA Cloud:

  • The discovery agent provides insight into the objects within the database using a knowledge graph for more efficient semantic lookups.
  • The multi-model agent augments with the specialist knowledge needed to use the advanced analysis engines.
  • The data agent supplements the need for SQL with natural language queries.
  • The admin agent assists with the analysis and optimization of the database.

SAP HANA Cloud enhances all data professionals with agentic teammates. Thanks additionally to in-memory speed, machine learning and AI libraries, access to multi-model engines, data-tiering, and the ability to scale, this cloud database provides the much-desired resources to build autonomous, intelligent, and responsive solutions that drive business process excellence.

To learn more about functionality and availability ...

(1) Be sure to watch these TechEd 2025 virtual session replays:

SAP HANA Cloud: The Database for Business AI

Accelerating Your AI Strategy with SAP HANA Cloud

 What’s Next for SAP HANA Cloud: Road Map and Innovation Highlights

(2) Make sure to read these blogs:

SAP HANA Cloud Becomes Agentic: Introducing Discovery Agent & Data Agent

What’s Next with SAP HANA Cloud – SAP TechEd 2025

Unleashing the Power of Trusted Data: SAP 2025 TechEd Announces Enhanced Data Product Capabilities

(3) Sign up for the free SAP HANA Cloud basic trial for a hands-on experience that includes a tutorial of the multi-model and data science capabilities of the database.

entry.title: Sales Order BOM - SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I’m facing an issue with Order BOM explosion in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Here’s the scenario:

  • I have a material TG11.

  • A Material BOM for TG11 works fine — BOM explosion happens correctly in the sales order.

  • I created a specific Order BOM for a sales order using the Manage Order Bill of Material app with:

    • Usage: 5 – Sales and Distribution

    • Plant correctly maintained

    • BOM released and valid for the order date

  • I created a sales order with the item TG11, but the BOM explosion does not happen.

  • I ensured the item category is correct with the Product Master Data for TG11 which is ERLA and when it comes to sales order it is showing TAQ(Pric at header level).

  • I tried to edit the sales order but then couldn't delete the material since it was saying the item is order bill of material. Even if I try to add a new line item with the same material TG11 the BOM is not exploding.

Question:

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
What is the take on SAP for the OR new requirement?

Oregon SB 906, which goes into effect on January 1, 2026. The law requires employers to provide a written explanation of payroll codes and related information to employees during onboarding.

 

Here’s a summary of the required disclosures:

• Earnings and deductions under ORS 652.610(1)

• All payroll codes used for pay rates and deductions, with detailed descriptions or definitions

• A comprehensive list of all pay rates employees may be eligible for

• All benefit deductions and contributions, and any deductions that may apply

• The purpose of deductions that may occur during a regular pay period

• Any allowances claimed as part of minimum wage

• Employer-provided benefits that may appear on itemized statements as contributions or deductions

 

Employers must update this information annually by January 1.

entry.title: Configuring SAP Business Workflow for parked documents (FIPP)
entry.content:
Hello experts,

during a SAP S/4HANA implementation, we have the requirement for parked document approvals via SAP Business Workflow (object type FIPP). As I am new to this topic, I need advice on the following issue:

So far, I did the configuration in customizing under ‘Make and Check Settings for Document Parking’, I created the workflow variant, assigned company code and defined release approval paths and procedures for parking documents including mentioning needed subworkflow WS51000020 (FIPP_SUBWFN2, two step approval except initiator). Also, I defined users for release authorizations for each approval level in OBWF. Beforehand, I activated the type linkage in transaction SWE2 for workflow framework WS00400032 for event CREATED as well as event linking in transaction OOCU is activated.

When I create a document with transaction FB01 and save it as completed, I check afterward in FBV3 and see the document is not released as expected. When I check workflow -> workflow overview, I see that workflow is not going through as expected. In display workflow log, I check the error message in work item and it says error in workflow customizing for document parking in OBWE. I checked the transaction and related customizing, but I am unable to find the hidden mistake.

Does anyone have an advice on how to solve this issue? Is this anything else to consider?

Thank you in advance for any advice on this matter

Kind regards

Jonas

entry.title: SAP TRM Daily Compounding Interest Calculation
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am trying to use SAP TRM on public cloud to calculate daily compounding interest in the same way as my Excel model. In Excel, each day’s interest is calculated on the sum of the original principal plus all previously accrued (unpaid) interest, so the interest compounds daily. However, in SAP, I am getting different results—SAP seems to be calculating interest only on the original principal, not including the previous day’s accrued interest in the base.

Excel Calculation Logic:

  • Each day’s interest base: Principal + Previous Day’s Cumulative Interest
  • Formula: Base Interest = (Principal + Previous Day’s Int Cmpd Bal) × Rate × Days / 360
  • This means the interest compounds daily, and the interest amount grows slightly each day as it is calculated on a growing balance

Difference in SAP currently: Each day’s interest = Principal × Rate / 360 (Previous interest is not included in the base)

I want SAP to calculate daily interest so that each day’s interest is based on the sum of the principal plus all previously accrued interest (i.e., true daily compounding), matching my Excel model. The goal is for SAP to use the previous day’s cumulative balance as the new base for interest calculation.

  • Is there a way to configure SAP so that it compounds interest daily, using the previous day’s cumulative balance as the new base for interest calculation?
  • Are there specific settings, calculation methods, or configuration steps in SAP that need to be enabled or adjusted to achieve this?
  • Has anyone successfully set up daily compounding interest in SAP to match this Excel logic? If so, could you share the configuration steps or any tips?

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Ciudad del Este 2025: El inicio de una nueva era para la comunidad SAP en Paraguay
entry.content:
El pasado 8 de noviembre, Ciudad del Este fue testigo de un evento histórico: el primer SAP Inside Track Paraguay. El Hotel Megal se convirtió en el epicentro del conocimiento, la innovación y la colaboración del ecosistema SAP en el país, reuniendo a consultores, líderes de proyectos, empresas y entusiastas de la tecnología en una jornada inolvidable.

SITCDE2025- SAP inside Track Paraguay 2025
Un hito para la comunidad SAP paraguaya
Este evento marcó un antes y un después para la comunidad tecnológica de Paraguay. Por primera vez, profesionales de SAP del país y la región se congregaron para compartir experiencias, aprender de casos reales y fortalecer las redes de colaboración que impulsan la transformación digital en América Latina.

Jornada completa de conocimiento e inspiración
La agenda del día estuvo cargada de contenido de alto valor, abarcando desde soluciones de gestión de talento humano hasta las últimas tendencias en inteligencia artificial y ciberseguridad cuántica.

Sesiones destacadas

SITCDE2025- SAP inside Track Paraguay 2025

SAP SuccessFactors: Transformando la gestión del talento
Carolina Salinas Glikin ( Qactions System) abrió la jornada explorando cómo las soluciones de gestión de capital humano de SAP están revolucionando la forma en que las organizaciones atraen, desarrollan y retienen talento.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Soluciones para empresas de todos los portes
Jean Tiago Baena ( Chess SAP Services) demostró cómo la nube pública de S/4HANA democratiza el acceso a tecnología de clase mundial, permitiendo que empresas de cualquier tamaño aceleren su transformación digital.

Ciberseguridad en la era cuántica
Carlos Benítez (Platinum Ciberseguridad) llevó a los asistentes al futuro de la seguridad informática, abordando los desafíos y oportunidades que presenta la computación cuántica para proteger los activos digitales empresariales.

Planificación financiera consolidada y facturación electrónica
Juan José Torres ( Roadmap IT) compartió estrategias prácticas para optimizar la gestión financiera corporativa y adaptarse a los requerimientos de facturación digital en la región.

Del control técnico a la transformación ágil
Esteban Hartzstein ( Tebyon Consulting) inspiró a la audiencia con su visión sobre cómo los profesionales SAP deben evolucionar para acompañar los cambios acelerados de la era digital.

Revolucionando procesos con inteligencia artificial
Douglas Rodrigues de Figueiredo ( @Teia_Connect ) exploró cómo la IA está transformando radicalmente la manera en que las empresas automatizan y optimizan sus operaciones.

SAP BTP y estrategias de migración a S/4HANA
Juan Pablo Barril  ( @Kuaa_Technology KUAATEC ) cerró las sesiones técnicas con una guía práctica sobre cómo aprovechar SAP Business Technology Platform para construir el camino hacia S/4HANA de manera exitosa.

Más que conferencias: una experiencia comunitaria
El evento no fue solo sobre tecnología. Los espacios de networking durante los coffee breaks permitieron que los asistentes intercambiaran ideas, fortalecieran relaciones profesionales y exploraran oportunidades de colaboración.

El cierre del evento fue memorable: sorteos, un brindis que celebró el éxito del día y un show musical que reflejó el espíritu cálido y acogedor de la comunidad paraguaya.


Un mensaje claro para el ecosistema SAP
El SAP Inside Track Ciudad del Este 2025 dejó lecciones fundamentales:
🔹La comunidad es el motor de la innovación – El conocimiento compartido acelera el crecimiento de todos
🔹Paraguay está listo para liderar – El talento y la pasión por la tecnología están presentes
🔹Colaboración sin fronteras – La transformación digital se construye juntos

Gratitud y próximos pasos
Este evento fue posible gracias al compromiso de todos los speakers, patrocinadores, organizadores y asistentes que creyeron en la importancia de construir comunidad. Cada presentación, cada conversación y cada conexión realizada el 8 de noviembre plantó una semilla para el futuro del ecosistema SAP en Paraguay.

¿Te lo perdiste? No te preocupes. Este es solo el comienzo. La comunidad SAP Paraguay ya está trabajando en los próximos eventos, y todos están invitados a ser parte de esta historia.

La transformación digital comienza con personas que comparten conocimiento. El SAP Inside Track Ciudad del Este 2025 demostró que Paraguay está más que preparado para escribir su propio capítulo en la historia de SAP en América Latina.

entry.title: Re: ABAP RAP - Enable/Disable Static Action on Child enti...
entry.content:
@Praveen547 

1. You can use the Feature Control to enable the button when the entity is in draft status (using the %is_draft field).

METHOD get_instance_features.
  LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(ls_key).
    IF ls_key-%is_draft = if_abap_behv=>mk-on.
      "enable the action
    ELSE.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDMETHOD.

2.  You can set SideEffects annotations for unbound actions in the annotations.xml file.

Please see the section Defining Side Effects on Unbound Actions in the document below:

https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/sdk/#/topic/18b17bdd49d1436fa9172cbb01e26544

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Curitiba 2025 — Um dia inesquecível de conhecimento, conexão e propósito
entry.content:
O SAP Inside Track Curitiba 2025 foi simplesmente inesquecível. Desde cedo, a energia contagiante tomou conta dos corredores da PUCPR, mostrando o poder da comunidade SAP quando se reúne com propósito e entusiasmo.

Credenciamento e boas-vindas

O credenciamento já mostrava o clima acolhedor do evento. Os participantes foram recebidos com muito carinho e um mimo especial: o chaveiro da nossa mascote de Curitiba, a capivara.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Para começar o dia da melhor forma, um coffee delicioso proporcionou os primeiros encontros, risadas e boas conversas.

 

 

 

Abertura oficial

Às 9h, tivemos a abertura oficial conduzida pela curadora Simone Azevedo, em um auditório lotado e repleto de energia.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

O curador Tiago Felipe apresentou um overview sobre a SAP Community, reforçando a importância de estarmos conectados e colaborando como comunidade.

 

 

 

 

 

Um momento de propósito

Um dos momentos mais emocionantes foi a mensagem das crianças da Instituição Incanto, que recebem apoio da SAP Community Curitiba.
Foi um lembrete inspirador de que, além da tecnologia, também construímos impacto social e propósito coletivo.

Confira a mensagem -->  https://www.instagram.com/reel/DQzDRUlEb2I/?igsh=MXV2bjN2dHg3aXlocg==

 

Condução e estrutura do evento

A condução do evento ficou por conta dos curadores Adriano Marques e Talis Moraes que atuaram como mestres de cerimônia, trazendo leveza e dinamismo a cada apresentação.

 

 

 

 

 

Tivemos também o apoio da PUCPR, que ofereceu toda a estrutura e acolhida, reforçando a parceria com a comunidade SAP em Curitiba.

 

 

 

 

Patrocinadores e conteúdo de alto nível

Os patrocinadores CHPRO e CVA trouxeram temas atuais e inspiradores, reforçando o quanto a parceria entre empresas e comunidade impulsiona o ecossistema SAP.

 

 

 

 


Na sequência, os speakers voluntários iniciaram uma verdadeira maratona de conhecimento, com apresentações de altíssima qualidade sobre IA, BTP, S&OP, Document AI, GMO e muito mais. Confira a playlist de peso que tivemos: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLavVF5azjc7kWao-Hg6mPAMfuHZ00JWwd&si=pAxbvL4PqjUX5yT7

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Voluntários: a força da comunidade em ação

O sucesso do evento só foi possível graças à dedicação dos voluntários, que atuaram em várias frentes: credenciamento, apoio técnico, comunicação, cabine de fotos, sorteios e até no famoso carrinho de picolé.
Cada um contribuiu com entusiasmo e comprometimento, mostrando na prática o valor da colaboração.

 

 

 

Experiências e conexões

Além das palestras, o evento contou com uma cabine de fotos que garantiu momentos divertidos e um painel com o nome de todos os participantes, simbolizando que a comunidade é feita por cada pessoa que participa.
Durante todo o dia, o networking foi intenso, com muitas trocas e novas conexões sendo formadas.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

E claro, o carrinho de picolé no período da tarde trouxe um momento leve e descontraído para encerrar as atividades com sabor especial.

 

 

 

 

 

Encerramento e celebração

O dia terminou com o tradicional sorteio final para quem ficou até o encerramento e com a foto oficial da comunidade, registrando o sentimento coletivo de realização e pertencimento.
O SAP Inside Track Curitiba 2025 foi mais do que um evento: foi sobre pessoas, propósito e colaboração.

 


Assista aos melhores momentos

Reviva a energia e os destaques do evento no vídeo oficial:
👉Assista aqui --> https://youtu.be/-Xrr_MtRGrs?si=tJZrWNCn6QQ4ZN-C

Agradecemos a todos que fizeram parte dessa edição e já deixamos o convite: ano que vem tem mais!
Esperamos todos em 2026 para mais um dia de troca, aprendizado e muita energia positiva.

Nosso agradecimento especial aos patrocinadores ouro CHPRO e CVA, e aos patrocinadores bronze FIORINET, Lupus e Aline Explica SAP , por acreditarem na força da SAP Community CWB e tornarem possível mais uma edição de sucesso do SAP Inside Track Curitiba.

entry.title: Re: How to Manual restriction of Transport import
entry.content:
Hi,

If the TR is managed by ChaRM document, then by default, it can only be imported via ChaRM. We have a project switch concept to control if the TR could be manually imported via STMS or not. Refer to KBA: 0002211597 for more details of the CTS project switch. This switch is closed for all systems by default when you create task list for the cycle.

BR

My understanding is that for this tag, it is expected that since it is set to false it is removed from the xml.  The behaviour of the template should still follow a false flag.  Please advise if you are seeing different behaviour.

Another option to explore is the use of a custom FTE field to display true FTE but setting the standard field to 1 (which is default if not used).  This blog and associated comments/questions is extremely thorough, so I suggest you review if you haven't already FTE and Proration examples in Compensation - SAP Community

Hope that helps.

Christian

entry.title: Re: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 1: Environment Setup
entry.content:
@BharathKumarVaddepalli 

Hi Bharath,

You should configure the destination in your BTP cockpit first using the Sales Order OData V4 API:
👉 SAP API Business Hub – CE_SALESORDER_0001

Scroll down to API Resources, where you’ll find the configuration details for the production URL. Use that as your System URI in the destination settings.
Once the destination is successfully created and tested, you can reference it directly in your Joule action project — no need to include the full API path inside the destination.

Hope this clarifies it!

— Teng Teng

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: SAP TechEd in Berlin special edition!
entry.content:
Last week happened one of the biggest highlights of the year for our SAP community! The SAP TechEd in Berlin was an incredible opportunity to bring together Developers, SAP Mentors and Champions, experts, and community members from all over the world for an inspiring few days filled with innovation, learning, and sharing. From the main keynote announcements to hands-on sessions and vibrant community meetups, SAP TechEd in Berlin 2025 was a true celebration of connections and technology.

Whether you joined us on-site or virtually, there were so many great announcements to take in from exciting updates in ABAP and AI, to the amazing energy of the SAP Community Clubhouse. Let’s take a closer look at some of the best moments and highlights!

Blog Posts about SAP TechEd in Berlin

SAP HANA Cloud goes agentic! 

SAP HANA Cloud is our cloud-native database as a service, delivering in-memory performance, multi-model data processing capabilities and elastic scale for intelligent applications. And to make these capabilities even more accessible and enable full power of the system, in early 2026, due to two new agents: the Discovery Agent and the Data Agent. The Discovery Agent is your companion to find and identify relevant tables, views, columns, and user-defined functions for any business case. The Data Agent converts natural-language intent into executable queries (e.g., SQL) to retrieve your data of interest. For this to be possible, SAP is expanding the SAP HANA Cloud knowledge graph engine with the ability to generate custom database-objects. Agents and the built-in knowledge graph help developers and business users find the right data through context and relationships. To understand more, SAP´s Thomas Hammer and  Shabana Samsudheen prepared two great blog posts with details about fully Agentic Multi-Model database.  

Read Thomas blog post here  

Read Shabana blog post here 

Paradigm Shift for Enterprise AI 

One of the biggest announcements at SAP TechEd in Berlin, was the launch of SAP table-native foundation model, pre-trained to understand your table-based business data out-of-the-box across a vast range of predictive tasks, without the need for task-specific training or fine-tuning. Until now, most organizations were using different AI specialist models for each prediction task, what makes the AI landscape slower. The launch of sap-rpt-1 (rpt stands for Relational Pretrained Transformer), it is designed to be a single universal AI engine table-native, for SAP´s customers and partners. The best part is the in-context learning capability, which means that sap-rpt-1 doesn´t require task-specific training, just need to receive labeled table row examples of your predictive task in-context, and the model delivers a highly accurate prediction. This engine was developed by our AI researchers (recently published to this year’s NeurIPS conference) and they made sure to bring more details on a blog post for our SAP Community. We highly recommend taking a good look and learning how to start using the preview version. 

Read Philipp Herzig blog post here 

Key Innovations for the ABAP Cloud development  

At SAP TechEd in Berlin, one of the main spotlights was the announcements that redefine the ABAP Cloud development experience. The big 4 key innovations are: ABAP entering the era of Agentic AI, ABAP LLMs available on GenAI Hub, ABAP AI capabilities will be supported in earlier releases, and ABAP is embracing an open IDE strategy with VS Code (Visual Studio Code). These advancements mark a milestone in the continuous work of unlocking intelligent automation, more productivity, and smarter enterprise solutions. SAP´s Sonja Lienard, published a full blog post with all the main details. If you have always been an ABAP fan and have been looking for a more modern experience, this is a must read!

Read Sonja Lienard blog post here 

SAP Community Clubhouse highlights 

For our SAP community, SAP TechEd in Berlin meant more than learning and developing skills, it was also an amazing opportunity to experience real-life connections with people who have been connected online for so many years. Inside the SAP Community, all members get to experience the feeling of being supported and offering help, while gaining valuable insights just through sharing and exchanging blog posts, forums, groups, and much more. At the SAP Community Clubhouse, all this experience was reflected in the interactions, presentations, and small chats. Our team is incredibly happy and grateful to everyone who could join. We know that being present at events like this can take a lot of work, and we highly appreciate everyone’s effort in participating and bringing so much positive energy. 

SAP Mentor Björn Schulz wrote an amazing recap (read the full blog post here) and shared some of his favorite parts of his first time at SAP TechEd. Check out some of his highlights: 

  • The Developer Keynote creatively showcased teamwork across technologies like HANA Cloud, AI, and Process Automation, embracing real-world “developer mistakes” that made it relatable. 
  • The Joule LLM for ABAP Developers promises smarter, context-aware coding support within the Business Technology Platform. 
  • Despite logistical hiccups, SAP TechEd 2025 offered valuable learning, networking, and a glimpse into the next era of ABAP and AI integration. The community spirit and new developer tools made it a rewarding experience. 

SAP Community news 

Updates for a better experience

Our SAP Community platform has gained some great new features over the past two weeks! We know how important it is for everyone to always have the best navigation experience possible, and these updates were designed to make connecting, sharing, and discovering content even easier. The main changes are:  

  • Filter My Content by Interaction Style: Allows to filter the My Content Page by distinct types of interaction (e.g., Answers and Replies), which makes it easier to find posts you have created. 
  • SAP Managed Tag Page: Now the width of the page has been extended to give a better overview of the list. 
  • TKB Documents: The last edited date has been added to TKB Documents, so now members can be more certain about when the information has been published and is still relatable.  

Got a minute? Tell us what you think!

We’d appreciate if you could take part in this short survey about SAP Community. By answering these 6 questions, you’re helping the community a lot! Access the survey link here

entry.title: Re: We want to rename an existing SAP service accounts (...
entry.content:
Please refer to KBA 2832479 - How to change the "display name" of a cloud system - SAP for Me

Abstract IMPORTANT INFORMATION for your reference:

  • Using this process to change the System Name only changes the display name in SAP for Me, not the permanent/default system name.
    There is no impact to any other connected system and access to the tenants if the system name/description is changed.
    • Since many cloud systems use the same generic name by default, it is hard to tell them apart when creating a case in SAP for Me. To help distinguish the various cloud tenants, customers can change the display name for cloud systems in SAP for Me by following the steps below.
  • The "System Name SAP Default" is the original/default tenant name and cannot be changed in SAP for Me. For this type of change, you must contact your SAP Account Manager and/or Implementation Partner directly as mentioned in KBA 2607673.
  • This self-service enables you to change the cloud system name and ID. SAP cloud systems are all systems that are managed by SAP Cloud Operation teams. This includes SAP Cloud Platform services, SAP Business By Design tenants, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Systems, SAP SuccessFactors instances, Concur services.
    Note: systems operated in the SAP HANA Enterprise Cloud systems (HEC) or Business Technology Platform (BTP) cannot be renamed with this service request. The names of HEC systems can be specified by SAP customer already before provisioning. The names of BTP systems can be changed directly in BTP by changing the corresponding display names, for example of Global Account, Subaccount, Space, or ServiceInstance.

entry.title: Re: UFL 'u212com.dll' that implements this function is mi...
entry.content:
Hello,

That error indicates CR is looking for possibly a 32 bit UFL, that file is the new UFL interface. If you write one in the proper format it will show up under the Formula Editor:

Microsoft said they were dropping COM years ago and had plan to replace it with .NET Framework, too many developers complained so they kept COM. At the time CR created the .NET components and committed and therefore dropped COM as well, the old RDC engine.

I doubt they are dropping it completely, CR still uses COM dll's and not likely able to drop it.... But I'm retired now so I don't know what SAP plans on doing with that kind of info...

A quick google search found this:

Microsoft is

not dropping support for COM DLLs. The Component Object Model (COM) and its associated Dynamic Link Libraries (DLLs) are fundamental components of the Windows operating system and are deeply integrated into many core features and applications. 

 
While Microsoft's focus has shifted towards newer technologies like the .NET framework for modern development, COM remains an essential part of maintaining backward compatibility and functionality within the Windows ecosystem. 
 
Key points:
 
  • Continued Importance: Many critical Windows functions, including ActiveX and OLE, rely heavily on COM.
  • Backward Compatibility: Removing support for COM would break an immense number of existing applications and software that rely on these components, which Microsoft aims to avoid.
  • Modern Alternatives: Microsoft encourages developers to use modern application development frameworks such as .NET moving forward, as they are considered superior to COM interfaces for many new projects.
  • Security: Microsoft has released guidance on securely loading libraries to prevent DLL-related attacks (like DLL hijacking), but this is a security measure, not an attempt to drop the technology itself. 
  •  
If you are experiencing issues with COM DLLs, they are likely related to specific program installations, system file corruption, or security settings, and can usually be resolved through standard troubleshooting steps like reinstalling the program or running system file checks. 

Anyways, have a look at the .NET UFL KBA to replace your existing UFL:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/1603381

You can change the UFL platform in Options:

Also be aware at the end of this year, 2025, SAP is dropping 32 bit CR .NET runtime, Note CR 2025 is a 64 bit application. You will need to develop your existing UFL for 64 bit Platform, or both if you plan to still support older CR 32 bit.

ALSO, CR dropped TTX support years ago, it's time to move to a different database. Note you can still use it in CR 2025 but highly recommend migrating to a SQL based data source.

Ido may have a solution for you to convert to a new data source...

entry.title: Unlocking the NPP: SAP Capabilities for Faster, Smarter Payments
entry.content:
The payments landscape is rapidly changing and in Australia the New Payments Platform ("NPP") is providing new infrastructure and capabilities.

Our customers want to understand more about what the NPP offers and how SAP is enabling the adoption of the new innovations, as well as the implications for data and payment processes.

This Blog series is the result of close collaboration between SAP and the Australian Payments Plus team, who are responsible for the NPP. It is a combined effort with the SAP ANZ localization team, notably my colleague @Bino_Philip  who has done much of the heavy lifting in defining the SAP response. Any errors are mine alone.

This is an evolving topic and whilst we’ll try to keep it current, please ensure you check the latest SAP documentation. Also bear in mind that until we publish a Development Roadmap, any comments on plans, intentions or other forward looking statements are personal views and not the official SAP position.

The series is planned as:

  1. Unlocking the NPP: SAP Capabilities for Faster, Smarter Payments
  2. Unlocking the NPP: Payments overview
  3. Unlocking the NPP: PayID
  4. Unlocking the NPP: PayTo

 

When will SAP be NPP ready?

This is the number one question we get on this topic, with a mass of confusion on the changes required for NPP and opportunities it presents.

The simple answer is that SAP is already NPP capable with many customers benefiting from real time payments and the additional capabilities available now.

However, to understand the full picture of what is available in SAP across the range of NPP capabilities, how we are delivering innovation and plans for the future, please read on.

 

So what is the NPP?

The New Payments Platform is:

  • Infrastructure which enables real time payments across Australia
  • Additional capabilities to improve security and simplify payments
  • Operated by Australian Payments Plus, whose members include the largest Banks, payment processors and businesses in Australia
  • The eventual replacement for the Bulk Electronic Clearing System (“BECS”) overseen by the Reserve Bank of Australia which will be decommissioned by June 2030

There is a mass of additional information at https://www.auspayplus.com.au/, including technical documentation and file mapping guidance.

The NPP is particularly relevant for payments where Payer and Payee use different Banks and the funds need to be transferred between them, for example from a Westpac account to an NAB account. The current BECS cross bank clearing is a periodic batch process on business days only whereas NPP is a real-time process available 24/7.

The NPP is already available and is being widely used for personal banking. NPP is the technology behind the Osko brand which enables real time payments using the PayID function, removing the need to share Bank details (BSB and Account number).

Note that NPP is currently only relevant to payments within Australia where the Sending and Receiving Banks and other Financial Institutions are connected to the NPP. They can connect directly as an “NPP Participants” which requires them to meet strict criteria and is largely limited to major Financial Institutions. Other entities who wish to provide NPP services (“Identified Institutions”) cannot connect directly and must have an agreement with a sponsoring NPP Participant. Where the Payer and Payee use the same Bank, the additional capabilities of NPP such as PayID, PayTo (see below) are still relevant, even though clearing of payments is handled within the Bank.

 

Architecture

Individuals and Corporates will continue to transact though their Bank which for simplicity we will assume is connected directly to the NPP as a “Participant”.

 

 

The role of SAP does not change: it will create the payment instructions, receive status updates and bank statements and enable the Bank integration. Additional message types such as for intraday bank statements and APIs may also be relevant.

We do not currently envisage any requirement for SAP systems to connect directly to the NPP.

 

NPP capabilities

The NPP is not just a change in technology or a new platform. It is designed and built to deliver significant business benefits and opportunities to innovate new business models. By sending payments using the NPP, SAP customers can start to leverage these current capabilities and investigate the benefits and opportunities they provide:

  • Real time payment clearing. This means that funds reach the payee in seconds not hours or days, improving cash flow. This has benefits in scenarios such as Public Sector benefits payments where recipients may have an urgent need, for example Bush fire related Disaster Recovery Payments. Similarly real time payments and their related status messages enable immediate execution of follow-on processes such as order credit unblock, sales order processing or delivery release with confidence that the funds have transferred.
  • Real time payment status messages. This means errors can be corrected faster and more payments reach the Payee on time.
  • 24/7 operations, 365 days a year. This provides additional flexibility in payment processing, from processing urgent payments to making payments precisely on the due date, even where this falls on a public holiday. It also assists with meeting compliance obligations, especially around payroll and superannuation.
  • PayID enables payments to be made using the Payee’s email, phone number, ABN or other identifier, without requiring their BSB and Bank Account details
  • PayTo agreements provide a greater degree of control and transparency for Direct Debit arrangements. The agreement or mandate is stored within the NPP and the Payer can approve, vary, end and define conditions (such as maximum amounts). The Payee needs to quote the agreement number rather than the BSB and Bank Account in the Direct Debit payment file.
  • Confirmation of Payee. This service reduces fraud by checking the name on the Bank Account with the name of the intended Payee recipient.

 

NPP payment files

We will go into more detail in the next Blog on the requirements around making a payment using NPP. The main point to be aware of is that whilst the NPP has specific requirements for payment file format and field mapping, the Bank determines what is required from SAP.

Each Bank will provide documentation on:

  • Payment file format - this is usually based on ISO20022 standard
  • NPP relevant fields, i.e. what is required to ensure processing by NPP rather than BECS

Once the file is created with the required format and fields, it can be sent to the Bank for processing using standard integration. We’ll discuss integration impacts and the challenge for SAP to create a standard NPP compliant solution in the next Blog. 

 

SAP Approach for NPP

Whilst the official SAP Roadmap is still being developed internally, our general approach can be understood as:

  • SAP solutions will be developed and delivered incrementally over future years, rather than as a single release.
  • SAP solutions will be based around a single common standard, such as the ISO standard format and not numerous variations such as for Bank specific formats.
  • SAP will focus on solutions for S/4HANA Cloud, both Public and Private Editions.

entry.title: Transparent Table Comparison
entry.content:
Table Comparison in DTV 1.7

With the newest release of the Data Transition Validation tool, DTV 1.7, transparent tables can now be validated. The tool has been enhanced to support the validation of both standard and custom transparent tables.

This recent feature expands the tool's validation capabilities, enabling it to support validation for 

  • SAP Reports and transactions (70+)
  • Custom reports of ALV output type
  • Custom namespace reports of ALV output type
  • Standard and custom transparent tables

This blog will demonstrate how you can utilize this new feature to compare transparent tables and view the validation results.

Table comparison

Click on “Define Test Specification” of the DTV project.

And then click on “Table”.

Click on Insert Row

Provide the table information as below

  • Transparent table name
  • Description
  • Functional Area
  • Functional Group

You can add multiple tables here.

You can use the Variant if you have any, and/or also provide split and condition parameter as per the requirement.

You can then perform Simulation (Not mandatory) and extract the result in the source system.

Once source extraction is done, similar process can be followed to extract the data in the target system.

Note: Use “Import Simulation Results” functionality to reuse the extraction result in “Data Extraction” step.

Once extraction is complete for both source and target systems, Data Evaluation can be triggered by selecting the tables and clicking on “Run Selected”

You can then check the evaluation result in the result tab.

Conclusion

With the addition of the table comparison feature, the scope of DTV validation has significantly broadened, making it more valuable in transition scenarios.

entry.title: SAP RE-FX Reversal process of Asset Retirement
entry.content:
Dear Gurus,

Please assist me on the reversal of an ROU asset retirement from a terminated contract.
Our scenario is as follows:

1. The IFRS16 lease contract was created and given notice June 30, 2025
2. Time slice was created for valuation (termination date +1 day) and proceeded with generation of cashflow as follows:
asset adjustment, depreciation and all postings ended as of June 29, 2025.
3. Receep has been posted Aug 2025 wherein Leasing retirement also posted.
Note that asset has not been deactivated.
4. Come November 2025, we need to reverse the asset retirement since termination did not pushed through and we have to continue the contract.
5. We now performed RECEEPRV to reverse valuation postings. However we are now encountering an error:
Errors occurred for asset XXXX XXXXXXXXXX in fiscal year 2025.

We have tried removing the given notice and reversing the RECEEP but we still encountered the same error when reversing the receep postings in November 2025.
We cannot reverse in the same period used in posting asset retirement as FI posting period is already closed for Aug 2025.

How do we reverse the asset retirement from SAP RE-FX after the lease termination has been cancelled?
What is the process for this?

Regards,
Lained33

entry.title: Re: Predicting Cycling Performance: SAP RPT-1 vs AI Chat Models and Strava
entry.content:
Hi Community,

 

" The comparison highlights clear patterns:

  • Strava remains the most accurate overall, with minimal deviation in both time and speed. Its specialized algorithm and access to large datasets give it a strong advantage.
  • SAP RPT-1 stands out as a powerful alternative. It delivered deterministic predictions, handled structured data effectively, and achieved results very close to reality. This shows its potential for numeric forecasting beyond sports—think production planning or predictive maintenance.
  • Gemini produced fast responses and understood units correctly, but its speed prediction was less precise.
  • Copilot and ChatGPT struggled with numeric interpretation. Copilot showed inconsistent outputs, while ChatGPT had the largest error in time prediction, likely due to misunderstanding units."

 

Thanks for your selfless sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

 

🙂

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: How to customize push notification payload to send additional data from S4 to SSAM
entry.content:
Currently in the standard push notification feature for SAP Service and Asset Manager, only the object key of particular object like Notification number for Notification and Order Id for Work Order is sent to mobile device in push notification payload. Sample payload:

{"notification":{"alert":"{\"title-loc-key\":\"NOTIF_TITLE_KEY\",\"title-loc-args\": [\"1000000000\"],\"loc-key\":\"NOTIF_BODY_KEY\",\"loc-args\": [\"1000000000\"]}","data":"{\"ObjectType\":\"Notification\",\"ObjectID\":\"1000000000\"}"}

But we want to show additional details in the push notification message like notification description and technical object description. We found the exact method which generates the payload. Class /MFND/CL_CORE_OTRIG_CPMS_PUSH  and method is BUILD_JSON_DATA.

But in this method, we are only able to get Object Key (Notification Number) and no other data. Also we are not able to fetch relevant data from table as notification is not yet saved.

Does anyone knows how can we handle this situation and how to send additional data like Technical object description in this payload. Any BAdI available for this or how to achieve this?

entry.title: Re: Dynamic ALV column creates default excel column col:
entry.content:
I tried to debug, found that the excel writer class appends the 'col:' in the beginning of the dynamic column if no fieldcatalog was passed. TO avoid this, fill the field catalog like below:

data(lt_field_catalog) = zcl_excel_common=>get_fieldcatalog( ip_table = <fs_table> ).

"Loop through the catalog, fill scrtext_s,scrtext_m,scrtext_l here.

"Pass when binding table

lo_worksheet->bind_table(
  EXPORTING
    ip_table         = <fs_table>
    it_field_catalog = lt_field_catalog

The generated excel should use the text you passed to your field catalog. The class doesn't automatically use the contents of your alv field catalog. Solved.

Hope this helps someone in the future.

Thanks!

Geoff

entry.title: Re: Dynamic ALV column creates default excel column col:
